favour.translation[0].definitions[0].def: something that you do for someone in order to help them or be kind to them
favour.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Could you do me a favour and tell Kelly I can’t make it?
He hired John as a favour to his father.
Paul, can I ask you a favor?
I owed him a favour so I couldn’t say no.
She helps me out when I have too much to do, and I return the favour when I can.
Do yourself a favour and make sure you get some time to yourself.
favour.translation[0].definitions[1].def: support, approval, or agreement for something such as a plan, idea, or system
favour.translation[0].definitions[1].not: find/rule in favour of somebody formal (=make a legal decision that supports someone)
favour.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: I talked to Susie about it, and she’s all in favor (=completely approves) of going.
In Sweden and other countries, nuclear power has lost favor.
All in favour (=used when asking people to vote on something by raising a hand)?
The idea may find favor with older people.
Employers are more likely to look with favour on experienced candidates.
288 members voted in favor of the ban.
Senior ministers spoke in favour of the proposal.
The vote was 60–59 in the government’s favor.
favour.translation[0].definitions[2].def: when someone or something is liked or approved of by people, or not liked or approved of
favour.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Radcliffe’s books began to find favour with the reading public.
Fountain pens have come back in favour.
Grammar-based teaching methods went out of favour in the 60s and 70s.
The island is very much in favour as a holiday destination.
The stock is currently out of favor with investors.
favour.translation[0].definitions[3].def: support that is given to one person or group and not to others, in a way that does not seem fair
favour.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Teachers should not show favour to any pupil.
favour.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: do somebody a favour
Could you do me a favour and lend me £5?
ask somebody a favour
I felt nervous about asking Stephen a favour.
owe somebody a favour
I owe you a favour for all the help you’ve given me.
return a favour
He helped me in the past and now he wanted me to return the favour.
a big favour
I’ve got a big favour to ask of you.
a great favour
He acted as though he’d done us a great favour by coming.
a small/little favour
Can you do me a small favour?
a special favour
I agreed to deliver the parcel as a special favour to Paul.
a personal favour
As a personal favour, he let us use the hall to rehearse.
a political favour
He was accused of granting political favours in return for illegal payments.
as a favour to somebody
She delivered the parcel as a favour to her sister.
do yourself a favour
Do yourself a favour and read as many books on the subject as possible.
favour.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to prefer someone or something to other things or people, especially when there are several to choose from
favour.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Both countries seem to favour the agreement.
loose clothing of the type favoured in Arab countries
Florida voters favored Bush over Gore by a very small margin.
favour.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to treat someone much better than someone else, in a way that is not fair
favour.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: a tax cut that favours rich people
a judicial system that favours men over women
favour.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to provide suitable conditions for something to happen
favour.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: The current economy does not favour the development of small businesses.
favour.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to look like one of your parents or grandparents
